Detailed Description

Definition in file cons.h.

Typedef Documentation

typedef struct sexp_impl* sexp

Symbolic expression.

The symbolic expression (sexp) is the basic abstract data type of lisp. Expressions may be atoms or cons pairs. The atom() predicate can be used to tell them apart. Sexp's are immutable.

Note:
This typedef is a facade, if you need access to the underlying structure, include cons_impl.h.

bool c_bool ( sexp  expr  ) 

Convert a lisp expression to a C bool.

In general, you should prefer to use atom() and eq() as they are. However, from time to time it will be necesssary to wrap them as c_bool(eq(a,b)) or c_bool(atom(p)).

Parameters:
expr Arbitrary lisp.
Returns:
true if expr is 't, false otherwise.

sexp car ( sexp  cons  ) 

Get the first element of a cons pair.

The name car comes from "Contents of Address Register". Steve Russell, the original lisp implementer, admits it was an uninspired name and suggests, in retrosect, that "first" would have been a better choice.

Parameters:
cons A cons pair, for example the head of a list.
Returns:
The first part of the pair.

sexp cdr ( sexp  cons  ) 

Get the second element of a cons pair.

The name cdr comes from "Contents of Decrement Register". Steve Russell, the original lisp implementer, suggests that "rest" would have been a better name.

Parameters:
cons A cons pair, for example the head of a list.
Returns:
The second part of the pair, often the tail of a list.

sexp cons ( sexp  expr_a,
sexp  expr_b 
)

Create a cons pair.

Because cons's may contain other cons's, they can be used to build quite complex data structures. The most common data structure in lisp is the list which is a simple cons chain. In a list, the first element of a cons, the car, is an atom, the second element of a cons, the cdr, is the next cons.

Parameters:
expr_a Arbitrary lisp.
expr_b arbitrary lisp.
Returns:
The newly constructed cons.

void gc_sexp ( sexp  expr  ) 

Garbage collect memory.

If expr is a cons, then the car and cdr will be recursively deleted as well if they are no longer needed.

Parameters:
expr The expression to free.

Definition at line 193 of file cons_impl.c.

sexp symbol ( const char *  str,
int  len 
)

Create an atom of a given string.

Atoms are so called because they do not have any sub-parts you can inspect, they cannot be further decomposed.

len is used to allow flexibility when parsing atoms from character buffers. Admittedly, it is a bit annoying when you have a null terminated str.

Parameters:
str A character string buffer.
len Length of str in characters.
Returns:
The atom representing str.
Note:
I wanted to call this method atom() to parallel cons(), but I was already using it for the predicate.
